noun.description: In full "golden milliarium": a gilded stone pillar erected during the reign of Augustus in the Forum in Rome below the temple of Saturn, and from which distances from Rome were calculated. Hence: a pillar or other marker serving a similar purpose in another city of the Roman Empire.

origin: Late 16th century; earliest use found in Henry Savile (1549–1622), mathematician and classical scholar. From classical Latin mīliārium, mīlliārium.
